I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Second  Teaching  Quality  Improvement  in 
Secondary Education Project (TQI-II).1 
   
2.  The project is a follow-on to the ongoing Teaching Quality Improvement in Secondary 
Education Project (TQI-I).2 In line with the government’s National Education Policy (NEP), the 
project will support the establishment of an integrated teacher education system to enhance the 
quality of teachers as a foundation for improving the overall quality of education.3 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Secondary education prepares students for employment at entry level and serves as a 
foundation  for  those  who  aspire  to  advanced  studies.  In  Bangladesh,  growth  in  primary 
education since the 1990s−gross enrollment rate increased from 63% in 1995 to 108% in 
2010−has resulted in a rapid expansion of the number of secondary schools, teachers, and 
enrollment and completion rates. Enrollment in secondary education has increased by more 
than 150% since 1990. The number of secondary education institutions almost doubled in the 
same period. In 2010, Bangladesh had 19,040 secondary schools (up from 18,500 in 2005) with 
a total enrollment of 7.9 million (53% girls), and 8,146 madrasahs (religious schools) with an 
enrollment of 1.7 million (57% girls). The gross enrollment rate was 47% (49% for girls) in 2010 
up from 43% (47% for girls) in 2005. Dropout rates have declined from 81% in 2005 (83% for 
girls)  to  57%  (54%  for  girls)  in  2010  for  secondary  grades  6–10.  The  pass  rates  for  the 
secondary school certificate have increased from 53% in 2005 to 78% in 2010; and from 59% in 
2005 to 72% in 2010 for the higher secondary school certificate. These achievements have 
been  possible  due  to  sustained  support  from  successive  governments  through  stipend 
programs,  curriculum  improvements,  teacher  development  and,  more  recently,  a  focus  on 
student performance. 
 
4.  The percentage of untrained teachers has declined from 60% in 2004 to 33% in 2010, 
which is still high. The proportion of female teachers has increased gradually from 20% in 2005 
to 23% in 2010. The government policy that at least 20% of teachers in rural schools and at 
least 40% in urban schools should be female supported an increase in the number of schools 
with female teachers. With the growth in the number of secondary institutions, the government’s 
administrative and supervisory capacity has been stretched, and it is now inadequate to fulfill its 
responsibilities  effectively.  The  government  recognizes  the  need  to  strengthen  effective 
monitoring and supervision of teacher training institutions and teachers in the classrooms to 
deliver quality education at all levels. 
 
5.  Continuing investment in teacher development is essential as international research 
shows that a common feature of all successful education systems is a clear focus on teacher 
quality. While Bangladesh has made significant progress in providing access to secondary 
education and has achieved gender parity up to grade 10, the quality of teaching, and hence

student learning, continues to be a major concern. Students who complete secondary education 
are unprepared to enter the workforce in higher job categories or continue to tertiary education. 
Poor and disadvantaged students are the most affected since they have limited choice of 
schools,  cannot  afford  additional  tuition,  and  usually  come  from  a  social  background  that 
attaches  limited  value  to  education.  Girls'  enrollment  has  improved  significantly,  but  their 
performance and retention deteriorate particularly after grade 9. In some areas, more girls are in 
schools  than  boys,  which  will  require measures  to  ensure  that  boys  attend  and  complete 
secondary education. 
 
6.  A major constraint to the provision of quality secondary education in Bangladesh is the 
shortage  of  qualified  and  trained  secondary  school  teachers.  Overall  coordination  and 
institutional links between teacher training and oversight institutions are weak. Teaching as a 
career is not valued and there are no incentives to reward teaching effort and excellence. Lack 
of  motivation  and  absenteeism  among  teachers  are  widespread  although  improving.  The 
problem is exacerbated by a lack of teacher and head teacher competency standards, on which 
to build a quality teacher training system. Also, teachers do not necessarily apply the modern 
student centered teaching skills acquired during training in the classroom. This is due to a 
multitude of transfer obstacles (overcrowded classes, lack of incentives, lack of appropriate 
teaching and learning materials, poor supervision, etc.), which are difficult to overcome.  
  
7.  TQI-I has contributed to the training of more than 220,000 secondary teachers through 
the adoption of policy reforms, the introduction of continuous professional development (CPD) 
programs, the strengthening of teacher training institutions, and the development of a pool of 
teacher trainers. TQI-I has targeted classroom teaching and learning through a CPD approach, 
which includes supporting and monitoring the usage of student centered teaching approaches. 
An initial assessment by TQI-I found that TQI-I training had made a significant impact on the 
classroom  performance  of  the  observed  teachers  in  more  than  70%  of  the  schools.  The 
assessment measured the usage of student centered teaching skills as instructed during the 
CPD. With the support of TQI-I, the Nongovernment Teachers Registration and Certification 
Authority (NTRCA) was established by law to institute a common set of quality standards for 
registering eligible teachers and recruiting them through school management committees. The 
government  also  established  the  National  Teacher  Education  Council  (NTEC)  to  common 
standards for teacher training providers. However, the NTEC has not become fully functional. 
The curriculum and textbooks are undergoing major revisions to move away from rote learning 
and into creative thinking and practical work skills. With these efforts, progress is being made 
toward developing and fully implementing an integrated teacher quality assurance system.  
 
8.  TQI-II draws on the following lessons from TQI-I and the country assistance program 
evaluation:4 (i)  changing  classroom  practices  and  teacher  behavior  requires  reinforcement 
through  CPD  instead  of  ad  hoc  one-off  training;  (ii)  pre-service  teacher  education  should 
emphasize  subject  knowledge  with  skills  in  pedagogy  anchored  in  approved  teacher 
competencies; (iii) in-service training should contribute to teacher qualification requirements for 
registration; (iv) effective teacher training requires strong coordination and shared commitment 
among central, field, and school stakeholders; (v) head teachers should serve as instructional 
leaders  to  monitor,  mentor,  and  motivate  teachers  to  apply  new  knowledge  and  skills  to 
transform teaching and learning in the classroom; (vi) initial efforts to establish an integrated 
teacher training system should be sustained with adequate expertise and budget; and (vii) 
project-based support from development partners should be harmonized and aligned with the 
country system and policy priorities.  
                                                
4  Asian Development Bank. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation: Bangladesh. Manila.

3 
 
 
9.  TQI-II  provides  the  following  special  features  and  innovations  to  enhance  teacher 
quality: (i) introducing standard competencies for teachers and head teachers, and designing all 
training based on standard competencies; (ii) strengthening school-level leadership to mentor 
and monitor teachers’ classroom performance; (iii) promoting partnerships between universities 
and teacher training colleges (TTCs) to improve teachers’ subject knowledge and pedagogical 
practices;  (iv)  developing  centers  of  excellence  at  selected  TTCs  for  teaching  English, 
mathematics, and science; (v) piloting computer-aided teaching and learning; (vi) providing 
incentives to make education more inclusive; and (vii) strengthening financial management 
procedures  to  mitigate fiduciary  risks. These features  and  innovations  are  building  on  the 
achievements and identified gaps of TQI-I.5  
 
10.  With the approval by Parliament of the NEP in 2010, the government embarked on a 
program of comprehensive reform to strengthen equitable access, quality, and relevance of 
education in Bangladesh. In 2011, a new phase of the primary education reform program 
started, with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) as one of the key partners. TQI-I and TQI-II 
are core building blocks in strengthening the quality of secondary education as envisaged in the 
NEP.  ADB  is  also  supporting  the  Ministry  of Education (MOE) to  develop  a  road map  to 
implement the NEP, with a focus on developing a sector-wide approach in secondary education, 
in consultation with development partners. While only a few development partners (ADB, the 
Canadian International Development Agency, the Department for International Development of 
the United Kingdom, the United Nations Children’s Fund [UNICEF], and the World Bank, etc.) 
are currently involved in secondary education, more are likely to join. A sector-wide approach is 
being  discussed  to  strengthen  overall  coordination  and  leadership  of  the  government  in 
partnership with the private sector and civil society. TQI-II is in line with the Country Partnership 
Strategy, 2011–2015 and the Sixth Five Year Plan; both emphasize improving the quality and 
relevance of education and the skills shortage.6   
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impact  of  TQI-II  is  improved  learning  outcomes  in  secondary  education.  The 
outcome is a strengthened, integrated, and more inclusive secondary teacher education system.  
 
C.  Outputs  
12.  The  outcome  will  be  achieved  through  four  outputs:  (i)  strengthened  teacher 
development  and  institutional  and  organizational  capacity;  (ii)  enhanced  teacher  training 
programs and delivery systems (pre-service, in-service including CPD); (iii) targeted support for 
inclusive education; and (iv) quality project management.  
 
13.  Output 1: Strengthened teacher development and institutional and organizational 
capacity.  The  project  will  support  the  NTEC,  NTRCA,  training  providers7,  and  DSHE  in 
developing  an  integrated  quality  assurance  system  of  setting  and  implementing  national 
standard  competencies for  teachers  and  head teachers  in  order to  improve  the quality  of 
secondary education teachers. This output will be achieved through the following four activities:

(i)  The institutional and policy framework will be strengthened to support the role of 
the NTEC, NTRCA, training providers, and DSHE. Roles and responsibilities for 
setting standard competencies for teachers and minimum standards for training 
providers,  registering  teachers  and  maintaining  registration,  aligning  teacher 
training programs with the competencies, and monitoring classroom performance 
will be articulated. A 1-year costed action plan will be prepared to implement 
institutional and organizational reforms. A study to propose an attractive teacher 
career path will be undertaken. 
(ii)  The capacity of the DSHE to use evidence-based planning and management to 
develop and monitor teacher quality will be strengthened. 
(iii)  School-level leadership will be strengthened to monitor and mentor teachers’ 
classroom performance. Head teachers will be trained to become instructional 
leaders. 
(iv)  Partnership arrangements with government, public and private training providers, 
and information technology companies will strengthen teacher education and 
teaching  practice.  The  results  orientation  of  the  existing  innovation  and 
development funding mechanisms will be further strengthened to improve the 
quality of training, teaching, and learning in secondary education. 
 
14.  Output 2: Enhanced teacher training programs and delivery systems. The project 
will  enhance  pre-service  education  and  in-service  training  (short-term  certificate training to 
prepare teachers to attain registration and CPD to upgrade teachers’ knowledge and skills). All 
training  programs  will  be  aligned  with  the  standard  competencies  for  teachers  and  head 
teachers  to  ensure  synergy  from  different  training  programs  within  an  integrated  teacher 
development framework. This output will be achieved through five activities:  
(i)  A  modernized  and  integrated  pre-service  teacher  education  program  will  be 
implemented. A bachelor’s degree program (3- or 4-year program) on a technical 
subject will be closely linked with a 1-year pedagogical training program. This will 
be achieved through establishing partnerships between universities and TTCs. 
The completion of both programs will lead to a bachelor’s degree of education or 
a  master’s  degree  of  education.    The  current  1-year  pedagogical  training 
program will be revised based on the standard competencies for teachers. 
(ii)  Teachers  will  be  assisted  to  attain  registration  and  formal  qualification  by 
providing  short-term  certificate  training  programs  and  adopting recognition  of 
prior learning schemes that will credit teachers for previous training.  
(iii)  Teachers  will  be  assisted  to  update  knowledge  and  skills  for  maintaining 
registration through CPD. CPD programs will be developed under the project with 
a special focus on computer-aided learning in the classroom.  
(iv)  Computer-aided teaching and learning will be piloted in 27 selected schools and 
TTCs covering the nine zones (administrative divisions for secondary education 
management). 
(v)  The capacity of teacher training providers will be strengthened by establishing 
training  facilities  in  51  cluster  center  schools,  including  public  and 
nongovernment schools, in areas that do not have any teacher training facilities. 
This capacity will also be enhanced by providing additional resources to eligible 
training providers, and by developing centers of excellence at selected TTCs for 
teaching English, mathematics, and science. 
  
15.  Output  3:  Targeted  support  for  inclusive  education.  The  project  will  support 
increasing  the  proportion  of female  teachers  and female members  of  school  management 
committees,  and  will  target  disadvantaged  areas  with  low  student  performance.  Inclusive

5 
 
education principles will be explicitly included in all teacher training activities. This output will be 
achieved through three main activities:  
(i)  Inclusiveness of education will be further strengthened by developing a new 
training policy, engaging civil society in advocacy, and targeting remedial classes 
in disadvantaged areas where student performance is lagging.  
(ii)  Participation of female teachers and teachers from disadvantaged groups will be 
increased by targeting scholarships to attract female teachers and by providing 
incentive  packages  to  teachers,  especially  women,  to  seek  appointments  in 
disadvantaged areas.  
(iii)  Proportion  of  female  members  in  school  management  committees  will  be 
increased  to  25%  by  running  advocacy  campaigns  and  providing  capacity 
building training.  
 
16.  Output 4: Quality project management. The project will improve project management, 
with a focus on financial management to mitigate risks associated with  organizing a large 
volume of training sessions. Monitoring and reporting will be strengthened with a focus on 
teacher performance. This output will be achieved through two activities:  
(i)  The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  will  be  strengthened  to  implement 
enhanced financial management procedures, especially for training sessions in 
the field, provide efficient support to the project steering committee (PSC) and 
project  implementation  committee  (PIC),  mobilize  partnership  and  ensure 
effective  working  arrangement  for  consultants.  The  MOE  will  ensure  timely 
mobilization of PMU staff with appropriate expertise.  
(ii)  Stronger monitoring and reporting will be ensured by the DSHE preparing an 
annual  teacher  performance  review  report,  the  Bangladesh  Bureau  of 
Educational  Information  and  Statistics  undertaking  a  biennial  census  of 
secondary  education  teachers,  and  the  PMU  preparing  regular  analytical 
monitoring and evaluation reports focusing on teacher performance.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The MOE will be the executing agency and the DSHE will be the implementing agency. 
An interministerial PSC will be established, chaired by the secretary of the MOE. The PSC will 
comprise  senior  representatives  from  MOE,  Ministry  of  Public  Administration,  Economic 
Relations  Division  and  Finance  Division  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  Planning  Commission, 
Implementation  Monitoring  and  Evaluation  Division  of  the  Ministry  of  Planning,  Ministry  of 
Primary  and  Mass  Education,  and  Ministry  of  Chittagong  Hill  Tracts  Affairs,  as  well  as 
representation  from  the  DSHE,  NTEC,  NTRCA,  the  National  Academy  for  Education 
Management, Bangladesh Open University, and the University Grants Commission. The PSC 
may co-opt other members as necessary. The PSC will meet at least every quarter. It will 
oversee TQI-II implementation, review project progress, approve the TQI-II annual budget, 
ensure timely decisions on critical interministerial policy and implementation issues, and provide 
operational guidance. A PIC will be established headed by the DSHE director general, with the 
TQI-II project director as the member-secretary, and representatives from the MOE and DSHE. 
In addition, selected technical experts from the MOE, DSHE, NTEC, NTRCA, the National 
Academy  for  Education  Management,  Bangladesh  Bureau  of  Educational  Information  and 
Statistics, universities, government and private TTCs, and Bangladesh Rural Advancement 
Committee education program will also be inducted for technical discussions. The TQI-I PMU, 
headed by a project director, will provide the basis for the new PMU, which will be enhanced 
with  additional  staff.  It  will  oversee  day-to-day  management  (including  financial  and 
procurement management), coordinate implementation, and mobilize technical support. The 
NTEC (headed by the minister of education) will oversee the development and approval of 
competencies, teacher registration, and partnerships (including twinning arrangements). The 
DSHE  will  serve  as  the  secretariat  of  the  NTEC  with  a  revised  composition,  roles,  and 
responsibilities. Implementation details are provided in the project administration manual.8

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
23.  Economic viability. The economic viability of the project has been assessed based on 
the benefits and costs associated with TQI-II. The benefits include improved teacher quality, 
and a reduction in internal inefficiency of education. The priced economic benefits include (i) 
direct benefit for teachers in terms of increased productivity and wages, (ii) improved internal 
efficiency for reducing system wastage caused by dropouts and repetition, and (iii) improved 
external efficiency for students with increased employability and higher wages (enhanced value 
for money). The three major streams of economic costs are (i) the direct project cost; (ii) indirect 
project-related costs including replacement and or upgrading of capital investments, such as 
computer  and  laboratory  equipment,  and  additional  operational  and  maintenance  costs 
generated by new infrastructure beyond the project period to sustain the project benefits; and 
(iii) costs to cover salary increases for newly trained teachers. The project is estimated to yield a 
net present value of $64.5 million. The economic internal rate of return associated with this net 
present value is estimated at 22.7%, assuming a discount rate of 12%. This suggests that TQI-II 
will be a sound investment.9 
 
                                                
9  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

24.  Fiscal  sustainability.  The  financial  affordability  and  sustainability  of  the  project  is 
analyzed  based  on  the  medium-term  budgetary  framework  in  the  National  Strategy  for 
Accelerated Poverty Reduction II, 2009–2012 and the Sixth Five Year Plan (footnote 6). The 
TQI-II allocation ranges from 3% to 8% of secondary education expenditure during the project 
period.  While  the  government  is  committed  to  allocate  the  required  budget  for  teacher 
development, government funds would be inadequate to meet training needs without ADB 
contribution.  Developing  an  integrated  teacher  development  system  will  require  sustained 
investments. The long-term sustainability of TQI-II will depend on two factors: (i) the ability of 
the  government  to  allocate  adequate  budget  for  teacher  development  over  time,  and  (ii) 
improvements in efficiency and quality. Given the positive outlook for gross domestic product 
growth and the NEP’s call for major reforms, allocations to the education sector are expected to 
increase and secondary education will receive more resources.  
  
B.  Governance 
  
25.  Rigorous financial due diligence work was carried out by reviewing the arrangements 
under the ongoing TQI-I. Based on this analysis the following measures are incorporated to 
improve  governance:  (i)  provision  of  adequate  relevant  staff  in  the  PMU;  (ii)  inclusion  of 
technical  experts  on  the  PIC  to  ensure  effective  implementation  of  technical  aspects  of 
proposed reforms, including aligning all types of teacher training with teacher and head teacher 
standard competencies; (iii) introduction of partnership arrangements for quality assurance; (iv) 
strengthening school-level leadership by institutionalizing monitoring of teachers’ classroom 
performance with DSHE oversight to ensure accountability; and (v) emphasis on advocacy 
campaigns for creating awareness, applying transparent criteria and procedures for selection of 
partner institutions and training programs, and disclosure of information on the project website. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with 
the  government,  MOE,  and  DSHE.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 8). 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.  There is a growing consensus among government, nongovernment organizations, and 
professionals that inclusion of marginalized groups in mainstream schooling is the only way to 
provide means for education and learning for all children. Despite rapid growth in secondary 
enrollment, around 57% of the students drop out. This rate is much higher for students from 
poor and disadvantaged groups. These students are most affected since they have limited 
educational options. Building on the TQI-I experience, TQI-II will focus on (i) providing remedial 
classes in the most lagging upazilas, where student performance in secondary and higher 
secondary  school  certificates  is  low;  (ii)  establishing  training  facilities  in  51  cluster  center 
schools in districts that do not have facilities to train teachers to serve disadvantaged groups; 
and (iii) piloting computer aided teaching and learning in 27 schools and TTCs to reduce poverty 
by enhancing access to better quality education. 
 
27.  Gender  and  development.  Bangladesh  has  achieved  gender  parity  in  secondary 
education enrollment and retention. The proportion of female teachers in secondary schools 
also  shows  an  increasing  trend.  The  provision  of  two  female  members  on  the  school 
management committees has created a positive environment for recruitment and retention of 
female teachers. The project includes (i) undertaking mass awareness programs to encourage 
and attract women to the teaching profession; (ii) raising general awareness with emphasis on 
the  positive  accomplishments  and  successes  of  female  teachers;  (iii)  structuring  incentive 
packages, especially for remote and rural areas, to motivate female teachers to join and remain

9 
 
in the teaching profession; and (iv) introducing mechanisms to increase the proportion of female 
members on school management committees (from 15.7% to 25% in 2016). The gender action 
plan  prepared  and  implemented  under  TQI-I  has  been  updated  to  (i)  help  upazilas  and 
secondary  education  institutions  in  rural  areas  achieve  the  target  of  at  least  20%  female 
teachers;  and  (ii)  enhance  the  proportion  of  female  members  on  school  management 
committees to at least 25%.10 
 
D.  Safeguards 
28.  Environment (category C). TQI-II will support construction of training facilities in 51 
cluster  center  schools.  The  project  has  adequate  arrangements  for  site  selection,  design, 
construction, operations, maintenance, and compliance measures, and is not expected to create 
any significant or long-term adverse environmental impact. An environmental assessment and 
review framework (EARF) has been prepared, and the subprojects for construction of training 
facilities  and  other  civil  works  will  be  identified  after  the  Board  approval.  The  EARF  has 
adequate  provisions  to  respond  to  any  environmental  issue  that  may  arise  during  TQI-II 
implementation. The borrower also has shown interest in adopting environmental safeguards 
and compliance measures, along with strengthening institutional capacity and committing to 
manage  environmental  risks  and  fully  implement  the  EARF.  The  DSHE  will  prepare  and 
disclose  semi-annual  monitoring  reports  that  describe  progress  with  implementation  of  the 
EARF, and compliance issues and corrective actions, if any. 
   
29.  Resettlement (category C). Social safeguard issues are not expected to arise since no 
major construction is anticipated. The proposed construction of training venues in cluster center 
schools is limited to the extension of small structures within the existing school premises. 
Subprojects for the construction of teaching facilities will be identified after the Board approval. 
Therefore, a resettlement framework has been prepared for the project, to ensure that any issue 
that may invoke ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement policy would be adequately addressed. The 
borrower has also demonstrated adequate institutional capacity, and commitment to manage 
social risks and properly implement the resettlement framework. 
 
30.  Indigenous  peoples  (category  B).  Three  districts—Bandarban,  Khagrachari,  and 
Rangamati, in Chittagong Hill Tracts—are home to the largest proportion of the country’s small 
ethnic communities. The rest are dispersed and generally live in isolated settlements among the 
mainstream  population.  Under  TQI-II,  one  outreach  center  established  under  TQI-I  will  be 
strengthened and two cluster center schools will be established to serve the target population. 
The subprojects for construction of teaching facilities will be identified after the Board approval. 
A small ethnic communities planning framework has been developed for the project, which 
defines possible mitigating measures.11 The borrower has also shown adequate institutional 
capacity and commitment to manage the social risks and to comply with information disclosure 
and consultation requirements through implementation of the framework. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
31.  Among  the  key  project  implementation  risks  and  mitigating  measures,  four  are 
summarized here. First, sufficient budget allocations must be provided to sustain continuous 
professional development activities after the project ends. Since these training programs should 
be provided regularly to reinforce changes in teaching and learning practices, the continuation 
                                                
10  Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
11  The planning framework is in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).

10 
 
of follow-up training is crucial under the government’s revenue budget. Second, teacher training 
must be made more responsive to quality improvements and labor market needs. This will be 
addressed  by  implementing  teacher  and  head  teacher  competencies,  with  head  teachers 
mentoring  teachers  and  monitoring  teachers’  classroom  performance.  The  project  also 
proposes partnering with selected universities to make training providers more relevant and 
responsive. Third, increased in-service teacher training is likely to disrupt regular classes since 
participating teachers may be out of class without proper arrangements for substitute teachers. 
TQI-II proposes to conduct all training programs during holidays or periods when classroom 
activities are least likely to be affected (after exams, or at the beginning of the academic year). 
Finally, fiduciary risks associated with training sessions conducted in the field will be mitigated 
by  enhancing  financial  management,  reducing  advances  for  training,  ensuring  quarterly 
reconciliation between bank statements and expenditure reporting from each training venue, 
and introducing a system of sample verification of training participants. In addition, to strengthen 
checks and balances no single agency will be made responsible for both teacher nomination for 
training programs and reporting participation of teachers in training. Selection of teachers for 
training will be done from an enhanced and up-to-date education management information 
system. 
  
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
32.  The government, MOE, and DSHE have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. The government, MOE, and DSHE 
have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan 
agreement.  
 
33.  To ensure funds are used for their intended purpose, the government and ADB will 
agree on the detailed eligibility criteria, selection process, and disbursement procedures for 
training  activities,  partnership  grants,  grants  for  innovation  and  development,  and  teacher 
incentive packages before withdrawals can be made for these expenditures. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR45,120,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Second 
Teaching Quality  Improvement  in  Secondary  Education  Project from ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such 
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft 
loan agreement presented to the Board. 
   
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
8 March 2012
